List
Fiction
INSOMNIA, by Stephen King. (Viking, $27.95.) A widower and a widow, victims of sleeplessness, behold sinister forces at work in their small Maine town.
DEBT OF HONOR, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $25.95.) Jack Ryan and C.I.A. agents vs. a Japanese plot to strike America's territory and economy.
TALTOS, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $25.) The survivor of a species of witches copes with his heritage; a sequel to "The Witching Hour" and "Lasher."
THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life.
NOTHING LASTS FOREVER, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $23.) Three women doctors in San Francisco contend with lovers, betrayers and killers.
POLITICALLY CORRECT BEDTIME STORIES, by James Finn Garner. (Macmillan, $8.95.) Classic tales respun to avoid offending current sensibilities.
THE BODY FARM, by Patricia Cornwell. (Scribners, $23.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta investigates the kidnapping and murder of a small North Carolina girl.
WILD HORSES, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $22.95.) A film maker pursues the secret confided to him by a dying racing expert.
THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, by Robert James Waller. (Warner, $16.95.) A photographer and a farmer's lonely wife in Iowa.
THE GIFT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.) A woman's casual visit to a small town changes the lives of many of its inhabitants, as well as her own.
THE CHAMBER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A lawyer represents a racist who is on death row for his part in a 1967 bombing in Mississippi.
MUTANT MESSAGE DOWN UNDER, by Marlo Morgan. (HarperCollins, $18.) In Australia's outback, an American woman learns about aboriginal philosophy.
ONE TRUE THING, by Anna Quindlen. (Random House, $22.) A woman who cared for her fatally ill mother is charged with killing her.
BROTHERS AND SISTERS, by Bebe Moore Campbell. (Putnam, $22.95.) The loyalties of a black woman are tested by colleagues' behavior in a Los Angeles bank.
A SON OF THE CIRCUS, by John Irving. (Random House, $25.) Returning to his native India, a Canadian physician encounters a murderer he once knew.

DON'T STAND TOO CLOSE TO A NAKED MAN, by Tim Allen. (Hyperion, $19.95.) Anecdotes and opinions.
THE HOT ZONE, by Richard Preston. (Random House, $23.) The discovery of a lethal virus.
COUPLEHOOD, by Paul Reiser. (Bantam, $19.95.) Essays on the ups and downs of marriage.
DOLLY, by Dolly Parton. (HarperCollins, $25.) The autobiography of the country singer.
BASEBALL, by Geoffrey C. Ward and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $60.) An illustrated history of the game.
ALL'S FAIR, by Mary Matalin and James Carville with Peter Knobler. (Random House and Simon & Schuster, $24.) The 1992 Presidential campaign.
THE BOOK OF VIRTUES, by William J. Bennett. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) Moral stories.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
NO ORDINARY TIME, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) The roles of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt during World War II.
MOTHERLESS DAUGHTERS, by Hope Edelman. (Addison-Wesley, $23.) Women whose mothers have died.
EMBRACED BY THE LIGHT, by Betty J. Eadie with Curtis Taylor. (Gold Leaf Press, $16.95.) A woman's near-death experience.
THE LAST BUS TO ALBUQUERQUE, by Lewis Grizzard. Edited by Gerrie Ferris. (Longstreet, $20.) A collection of essays by the late syndicated humorist.
TRUE NORTH, by Jill Ker Conway. (Knopf, $23.) A memoir by a former president of Smith College.
RUNNING FROM SAFETY, by Richard Bach. (Morrow, $23.) A middle-aged man's reflections on life.
BETTER THAN SEX, by Hunter S. Thompson. (Random House, $23.) The 1992 Presidential campaign as seen by the gonzo journalist.
THE KENNEDY WOMEN, by Laurence Leamer. (Villard, $27.50.) Five generations of a family.

And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE BELL CURVE: Intelligence and Class Structure in American Life, by Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray. (Free Press, $30.) The evidence the authors see indicates to them that society is layered in rough accordance with I.Q. and that I.Q. is largely heritable, findings they believe society needs to take note of. THE FOLLOWING STORY, by Cees Nooteboom. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace, $14.95.) An insignificant man who has experienced transformation by imagination awaits his turn at death in this "Eurofable" by a Dutch novelist. IN THE LAKE OF THE WOODS, by Tim O'Brien. (Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) This grim, telling novel deals with the incapacity to register reality of a politician whose disappearance from the record of the My Lai massacre precedes his vanishing from the earth. NATURALIST, by Edward O. Wilson. (Shearwater/Island Press, $24.95.) A memoir by a distinguished biologist who has never lost his boyhood enchantment with nature, though he has suffered abuse for his sociobiological synthesis. THE PHYSICS OF IMMORTALITY: Modern Cosmology, God and the Resurrection of the Dead, by Frank J. Tipler. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Life is eternal, says a mathematical physicist, given the nature of this universe; a 123-page mathematical appendix is offered for skeptics. THE SCIENCE OF DESIRE: The Search for the Gay Gene and the Biology of Behavior, by Dean Hamer and Peter Copeland. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A readable, cautious account, by a scientist and a journalist, of an investigation into whether homosexuality is genetically determined. SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS, by David Guterson. (Harcourt Brace, $21.95.) A handsomely constructed, densely packed first novel whose characters are those who suffered and those who profited from the internment of Japanese-Americans in World War II, called upon by a criminal trial to act decently later on. STALIN AND THE BOMB: The Soviet Union and Atomic Energy, 1939-1956, by David Holloway. (Yale University, $30.) A superb history, showing how Stalin both helped and hindered his nuclear scientists, and telling more about the Soviet H-bomb project than is known about our own. TAFT, by Ann Patchett. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) This generous novel concerns abandonment, dislocation and the recovery of community in a Memphis bar whose owner is a surrogate parent to two displaced teen-agers. WHAT I LIVED FOR, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $23.95.) Ms. Oates shrewdly dissects the national myths of manhood and success in a novel whose easily confused hero understands less than the reader does of what passes through his own mind. WHO WILL RUN THE FROG HOSPITAL? by Lorrie Moore. (Knopf, $20.) A sad, witty, disillusioned fairy tale whose heroine, approaching 40, recalls the illusion of limitless possibility she used to feel.
